paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Whether intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine can create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 therapy

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Multiple murine tumor models receiving intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 combination therapy, pooled across repeat experiments

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Matched controls receiving vaccine-only, ICI-only, or vehicle treatment across multiple experiments

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective metastatic cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, analyzed retrospectively and compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Patients in the retrospective cohort who had prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination before ICI treatment

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human unvaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Patients in the retrospective cohort who had not received SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination before ICI treatment

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors
Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings
